text:
Shipping Containers
Experimentation with shipping containers is still in
progress. The film cans have been abandoned. It v;as found that the
lids of these cans too often pinched off a foot or two of tape. In
some cases part of the program was missing. They also get
mashed out of shape rather quickly and thus there is added
danger of tape damage.
We are currently using fiber film shippers and cardboard
wrappers which fit around the tape in its original box.
A campaign has also been launched to get all stations to
fasten the ends of the reels so that the tape doesnft unwind during
shipment. Unwinding results very often in a pinched fold across the
tape v/hich is soon followed by a break.
Shipping Labels
As mentioned earlier we have had to discontinue typing the
shipping labels for all stations. A complete adriressograph service
is available to the University and this is, perhaps, the best ultimate
solution to the label problem. It would also be possible to have labels
printed. We could also have a rubber stamp made for each station.
The addressograph plates could be used to address envelopes, so if
this service can be obtained at a moderate cost we will have the
plates made.
Mail Service
The economy drive in the Post-Office Department has
resulted in poor mail service. For example: It recently took seven
days for a tape to get to Toledo, Ohio from East Lansing, Michigan.
It took a tape two and a half weeks to get from Urbana, Illinois
to Atlanta, Georgia 2
Experience seems to indicate that this is not a general
occurance, but it does happen rather frequently. The whole subject
of the reliability of mail service needs further investigation. It
may be necessary to pay premium postage, change to Railway Express,
or extend the time allowed for tape delivery. Neither of the last
two possibilities seems desirable.
-16-
